column2: Half the little penguin chicks from this yearâ€™s breeding season on Penguin Island in Western Australia have died, as the colony dwindles and researchers accuse the state government of failing to act. It is thought up to 20 chicks, which represented 10% of the colony, were lost after New Yearâ€™s Day when their parents were unable to feed them, resulting in the worst breeding season since 2011.  Penguins in the colony, where numbers have dropped from around 2,000 birds 15 years ago to around 250, began the breeding season late after heavy rains brought by La NiÃ±a improved their food supply. The resulting chicks survived a heatwave over the Christmas weekend with the help of ice blocks dropped into their nests by researchers â€“ anything above 35C can be lethal, as temperatures inside nests can be up to 3C higher â€“ but things quickly took a turn. Adult penguins must replace their feathers once a year, usually in December and January, and are unable to enter the water to hunt during this time. When this occurs, they cannot feed their chicks and the birds begin to starve. When their parents do not return to feed them, the chicks will leave their nests to enter the water before they are strong enough. While it is impossible to know the fate of every individual bird, Dr Erin Clitheroe, who has been conducting surveys of nests on Penguin Island for 14 years and wrote her PhD on the colony, said underweight chicks have a slim chance of survival. â€œIf theyâ€™re abandoned and are leaving the nest at a weight under 900g, they donâ€™t have very much chance of survival, but under 800g is a death sentence,â€ Clitheroe said. During the recent survey the lightest chick weighed just 400g and was found dead a few days later near its nest. The colony is the second northernmost population to be found in Australia. To remain stable at its current size, every breeding pair must successfully raise one chick each season. Dr Joe Fontaine from Murdoch University described the deaths as â€œunnecessaryâ€. â€œIt was already going to be a really bad year, then it got worse,â€ Fontaine said. â€œThe simplest way to explain it is that demography is inescapable. â€œWhen you wipe out half the yearâ€™s reproduction and the population is already in trouble, youâ€™re making it that much harder for the population to ever recover.â€ Clitheroe first recommended the WA Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (DBCA) set up an emergency feeding program in September to ensure the birdsâ€™ survival and the continuation of the colony. When it was learned the chicks were in trouble, Fontaine made a formal request with DBCA for an emergency response but no action was taken in time. The Guardian has seen an email from DBCA rejecting the request as the department believed it was illegal for researchers to take the birds for longer than a 72-hour period. â€œThey were reluctant to act and the consequence was a nondecision decision,â€ Fontaine said. â€œThis is a slow-moving mess that consigned half of this yearâ€™s reproduction to death.â€ The department was contacted for comment but did not provide a response by deadline. Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning Dawn Jecks, a councillor with Rockingham city council and the organiser behind the Save Rockinghamâ€™s Little Penguin campaign, said her â€œheart sankâ€ when she learned of the deaths. â€œThe bottom line is, unless responsive and accountable institutional processes are in place, decisions will be delayed and extinctions will occur,â€ she said. Jecks said that while DBCA has been actively promoting tourism on the island, plans to construct new infrastructure should be called off and foot traffic into the area should be stopped to take the pressure off the colony while it recovers. â€œAt the moment thereâ€™s just inertia. Itâ€™s dire â€“ how do we explain to our grandkids who ask why there are no penguins on Penguin Island and we did nothing to save them?â€ Clitheroe said while the colonyâ€™s circumstances were linked directly to climate change, it â€œwas not inevitableâ€ the colony would die out. She said catch, feed and release conservation programs in South Africa offered a â€œfantastic exampleâ€ that could be followed, or birds could be fed in their nests. She also said a broader climate change adaptation strategy should be considered â€“ a call echoed by Nic Dunlop, citizen science program coordinator with Conservation Council WA. â€œWe need to give it a go and even if we fail, thereâ€™s a lot to be learned which may be useful in protecting other species,â€ Dunlop said. â€œWe hope the agency will come along with it but that remains to be seen.â€
column4: Half this yearâ€™s little penguin chicks on WAâ€™s Penguin Island wiped out as colony dwindles

column2: New Zealandâ€™s navy has conducted an unusual mercy mission to retrieve two people stranded in Singapore for 18 months due to Covid-19. A medical condition meant the two could not fly to New Zealand, and their shrinking bank balance made staying in Singapore difficult.  According to documents released under the Official Information Act, the mission occurred after an adviser to New Zealandâ€™s high commission to Singapore interceded on the pairâ€™s behalf, saying their position was â€œvery uniqueâ€ and he feared â€œtheir situation could turn into one that is even worseâ€. The couple, whose case was first reported by Stuff, received a special exemption to travel on board the HMNZS Canterbury, which was being refurbished in Singapore at the time. The ship left Singapore in November 2021. The journey took 19 days, meaning the couple did not need to quarantine upon arrival in New Zealand.Disclosed government emails demonstrate a concern the mission could set an inconvenient precedent. However, one official wrote: â€œIt is not a Dunkirk-style evacuation of [New Zealanders] from south-east Asia.â€ In a separate email the official wrote: â€œIf we establish a precedent whereby people who have no ability to fly find themselves at a place where there is a [navy] vessel, that is heading for [New Zealand], with available space and medical staff on board, I can live with that.â€ New Zealandâ€™s foreign ministry noted that the case involved a â€œvery specific and unusual set of circumstancesâ€ and declined to comment further.
column4: New Zealand navy rescues duo stuck in Singapore for 18 months

column2: Boris Johnsonâ€™s grip on the prime ministership is openly questioned on the front pages, as unease in Tory ranks grows over the latest revelations of garden parties at No 10 at a time when gatherings were limited to one person.
